SpaceX has 145,000 subscribers at this point. There are about 750,000 people who have ordered Starlink in addition to the 145,000. What's holding them back is not enough satellites. What happens is SpaceX creates cells. Think of them like a 10 square mile area. They can only have a certain amount of subscribers in each cell or download speeds will slow. They are playing a balancing act.


With 145,000 subs they get $14.5 million in gross monthly income or $175 million a year. They sell the hardware about $1000 below cost which means they make no money from a sub until 10 months. Add 145k plus 750k and you get 895k and $89.5 million a month.


I estimate SpaceX has already lost 200 satellites for a variety of reasons not counting the 40 they lost a few days ago. Satellites fail and these ones only cost about $½ million each. We don't know the life expectancy but at this low Earth orbit it will be low. 5 to 10 years max. At 5 years they would have to replace  8,400 a year. That's $4.2 billion a year not including launch cost.

I design RF Amplifiers which combine the output power of up to 32 transistors to reach full power, somewhat similar way to the way the 29-32 Raptors work on the Starship Booster. The hardest part of this is maintaining stability. Any feedback from the output to the any of the inputs results in severe instability and oscillation. Basically to work the all inputs need to be isolated from each other. It can also be modeled and simulated. Imagine a multi-vibrator circuit repeated 32 times. It can be done but it took me 3 years and several attempts to understand all the different causes of instability.
The other thing which concerns me is the booster positional accuracy required for the two catcher arms to work as intended. Perhaps a solution which is more tolerant of any landing positional errors is needed?

SpaceX say they are short on oxygen? The plan on Mars is to crack water (H2O) into Hydrogen (H) and Oxygen (O2), and Carbon Dioxide (CO2) into Carbon (C) and Oxygen (O2), and then use the Hydrogen and Carbon to make Methane (CH4) for fuel, with the Oxygen (O2) left over as the other component. So as SpaceX will need that technology for Mars, why not use it on Earth to make their own Oxygen NOW? It's tech they will need to develop anyway! They could EASILY crack water (which is abundant on Earth - they could even distill sea water and use that) into Hydrogen and Oxygen, and then either supercool the oxygen or just put it under enough pressure, to get it to what they need for their rockets now. Science has a solution for every problem - surely they figured that out?

some concerns about the winds, when super-heavy launches and comes down to be captured: at Launch You preferably need some breeze to seawards direction, to dilute or blow away the exhausts (maybe needs CO2 and oxygen monitoring around the exhaust-plume). 15 min later You preferably want no breeze, no gusty wind, when the Heavy comes back to the tower. What You should worry about is a situation, when the weather doesn't play ball? To properly steer the rocket, we would need many 3_D inputs of real-time wind indicators, precise measurements at multiple heights (multiple balloons?), to have a 3_D model of the actual winds encountered by the returning rocket. LIDAR-Lasers could do the measurements, by measuring the movement of aerosols in the air.
Another proposal might be a row of 400_m high bars around the landing site like they have (smaller ones) in the harbor of Rotterdam to protect the biggest container ships from dangling around in stormy weather.
While this huge protective wind-shield structure may do some good, on the other hand, it would also attract storms and meteorologic low-pressure areas, similar as wind-parks do. Windmills also initiate twisters, occasionally so strong, that they can lift roof tiles!

That thing he said about working with a sense of urgency kinda resonated with me. He's right. After the moon landings in the late 60's/early 70's, the US got comfy with low earth orbit before retiring the shuttle with no backup plan ready. The Soyuz was a thing, we could just use that. We stagnated because commercial companies and Progress could resupply the ISS, while Soyuz could launch crew. That was going to be the reality of human spaceflight up until the retirement of the ISS, and then after that, we would have nothing. It would just be China launching people up to their own space station and interplanetary probes. No chance of humans becoming multiplanetary.

Then the commercial crew program finally started to quite literally take off, and now seeing the progress being done on SuperHeavy and Starship is giving me hope that we may actually return to the moon and eventually land on Mars.

👨🏿‍🚀🐘Quite the "beehive" of activity. Taylor Lee and Mr. Patel are quite encouraging. For example: everything on joining SpaceX to how the welding of jacks and shin plates for the stands are conducted. The launching of the "ring" (ie. holding down the inside with regards to steel thickness, line boring, reduction and mass welding of thick steel) to increase mile/hour  ratio for booster and ship, is quite enticing too. Multiplanetary representation and urgency (becoming an interplanetary species as soon as possible) are important elements in addition. The iota of progress.

I really enjoyed this "you are there" walking tour of the launch site (where the booster meets the ship) but there was this one transcendent moment on top of the half-built launch mount where I felt the entirety of my humanity reflected in the urgency of SpaceX.  I was in my virtual hardhat, watching my footing but listening intently to the plan to lift ungodly amounts of metal tomorrow, and I stayed resolute as our CEO talked about his desire to achieve a legacy beyond his grave: a self-sustaining city on Mars.  If that doesn't floor you, your heart ain't beating.

Tim,
Think you were onto something RE: cooling the base of the flaps with methane left in the tanks.

Here's an Optimization:
How much dry-ice would it take to turn that into a non-combustible mixture on reentry and could the dry-ice be located to cool hotspots in the tanks or structure found by iterating so it provides two functions for the same weight? Keeping dry-ice isolated in a bath of cryogenic methane or ox shouldn't require much more than a bag, and if it melts late in the game, that's fine as long as it doesn't contaminate the fuel or ox, and keeps the methane from adding heat by burning on reentry.

(I get that it's still cooler than the plasma, but even better if a little dry-ice mass can replace expensive/complex/time-consuming insulation panels by also making it incombustible)

I've worked with a lot of people over the years and there is no mistaking an excellent work culture when you see it.   When the lead has people follow the objective as opposed to "follow me," the team is free to work together rather than gain closer access to the "boss" for status.   Your place in the organization becomes about the ability to contribute with your peers and how that becomes self rewarding and sustaining.   It also breeds a workforce that can really succeed together on their own just given clear goals.   Best way to build a company.

I used to be a maritime deck officer and the urgency at spacex reminded me of the urgency when a ship is pulled into a drydock. The urgency there is because every single day that a ship spends in drydock, it costs them A LOT of money and also the ship is not earning money during that time. Profit motive makes you do that, but for Elon, it's purely principal. He rushes because there is a downward trend towards space exploration and he wishes to turn that around. He wishes to make Mars sustainable before the supply chain collapse on Earth. He knows what's coming for Earth, but as long as Earth will have Mars to keep it's information safe, Earth can be saved.

If life gets much, just stop for a few minutes and reflect. Paper and pen still works, and this helps to calm you to make the right decision. Hire people who have your back, and get someone on board who can handle a lot of the 'people talking' and admin work. This is your life, I get it, but at what point should you be unhappy every day or worried? Say 'no!' to that, and wake up, realising the small things you have is what is most precious. I remember watching the U.S. space program in action in the 60’s and how ponderous it was in relation to the Starship The ruthless way he and the crew pare out unnecessary mechanisms and functions to get to a rocket that will probably work well enough to get most of the way through the mission before blowing up. All so they can modify the next one to do better.
1. Musk has access to flight computers that are able to run an extremely complicated flight profile autonomously. Nowhere near true in the 60’s.
2. Musk bankrolls and controls his own operation. He deals on a near peer basis with bureaucrats & politicians. He’s not taxpayer funded.
Those two things give him enormous freedom to operate the way he does.

Their job could be coming to an end in a month or two and would need to contract out with an other company, and more than likely travel a great distance to do so. Little do they know, they will soon be offered some much needed and (I’m almost certain) appreciated stability, for them and for their families. To me, that was a neat little moment to witness.

So, here we are, barely a week (maybe 8 days?) after this video was shot, and the launch pad (orbital pad) has been completed (at least to where they could stack rockets on the base), the booster (B-4) was moved onto it, and then the Starship (Ship 20) was stacked on top of it. Of course, they've already been taken down, and returned to respective high-bays / assembly areas for "Finishing" touches. What we see here is that what Mr. Musk said on Parts 1 and 2 is absolutely critical to understand: The launchpad (Stage 0?) is far more work, and far more critical to get right than any of the particular rocket iterations. Building a rocket is relatively simple and straightforward; building a launchpad is hard.

That said, the "Urgency" question is also quite interesting. Our NASA programs were "Tending to zero" Mr. Musk said (no astronauts launched on American made rockets for over a decade). So, we are now working as if there could be a meteor headed for earth in the next week or so. Interesting, interesting, interesting! The workers were actually told that! They are finding it difficult to keep up the frantic pace, as the manufacturers cannot seem to supply them with enough parts to keep all these guys busy! Well, at least it sounded like there was a somewhat of a shortage of things to do for some of those guys down there. They were going to clear the area around the orbital launchpad while they hoisted the base onto the towers, and send all the workers over to the tank / propellant farm to work over there. He called it "An army of guys" that they would be sending over there.

It's interesting, it's impressive, it's all the hallmarks of a dedicated force working together to achieve a common goal that is very far out there in the future, but is perceived to be a real problem here and now today. Not just any old problem mind you, but a WORLD CRITICAL problem that they are trying to solve! In my career, I worked on a few projects that had "World critical" status, and the government generally sits around watching, cataloging and documenting every single step in the process, which as you can imagine, massively slows things down. The rate of change and progress at SpaceX is therefore more than impressive, and is exceedingly refreshing to watch!

The government winds up with $300 hammers and $1,500 toilet seats because of the massive amounts of oversight and so on in those world critical programs, and people flinch. I don't think you'll ever see that from a program such as SpaceX is putting together. From what I've seen, they are continuing to innovate and improve designs, steadily, and cost effectively, in order to continue to drive the costs down of taking a pound of material (or bodies) to space, and ultimately to other planets.

Having been in the military as a senior officer, I had the opportunity to interact with many General officers over the years. I was never one to be too intimidated by rank, but I'd always feel a little tense when walking around my unit with a General who was there to check on things. Elon seems like a down to Earth dude, but I don't doubt he is tough on his people when things aren't what he expects. You can see it in everyone's eyes when he walks up. They want to show him they're doing good work. I can only imagine the pressure they're under. It's awesome to watch. Nothing historic will happen without people making it happen. History will remember Elon, but all of us will remember the army of unnamed people in videos like this that are making history while we watch. Thank you, Elon. Thank you unnamed badasses. Thank you, Tim. Thank you, YouTube for allowing us to witness history in real-time.

-The vacuum and the atmosphere optimized engines are because of the diameter of the circumference and the length of the cone.
Then why don't make like the fighter planes and make the cone move so it's always on the optimal diameter?

Explanation: I know rocket engines are powerful and they need one piece heat resistant cones with refrigeration to prevent them from melting. But it you cut the cone of the engine into 8-10 parts and then make them fit so thrust doesn't escape from holes between the parts and move them along side the rocket while it's flying you can make them have a smaller diameter while launching for peak water level efficiency and then make the move with servos/hydraulics "must have enough strength to prevent the parts from separation while allowing them to fold and open like petals of a flower" so it gets wider and keeps the efficiency along side the altitudes increases. It would be like having the atmosphere and the space optimized engines in one + all the steps between.

After thinking about in-space refueling, I have a question: Would it make sense to put a refueling station in orbit so Star Ship missions could get all their fuel with one stop?

Potential Pros:
- The refueling station could shade itself with solar panels which would also collect the power required to transfer fuel and to maintain stored fuel within thermal parameters.

- The refueling station could also have one or more robots designed to autonomously drag fuel lines to nearby Star Ships, ... be they tankers or Star Ships destined for other destinations in space.

The initial refueling station could be a single Star Ship which launches with solar panels, fuel lines and a robot. Its own fuel-tanks would be empty when it achieves orbit. These could be refilled by tankers before the next Star Ship mission.

Starship refueling!

Side by side refueling They could use a semi-flexible hose 200 feet long, there is no reason to be that close together! And if they are even smarter, it would be made up of 4 x 50 feet sections, just Incase a section or two were damaged in some way! A built in redundancy is a good way to go! 4 hose sections 4 inline pumps.

A 50 foot spacing is plenty room to make the whole process safe! The hole pump section is a inline magnetically rotating pump on the inside of the house They were developed 20 years ago, for inline heart pumps, that would not damage blood cells, but the person would not have a heart beat. And because is it magnetic driven, there is no chance of a spark causing a explosion.

They also could connect 1 up to 4 hoses, to each ship, to speed up the refueling process!

Over the last maybe 90 minutes, I am sure I read close to 200 of these comments, and left several of my own. I'm 74, and I excitedly watched when Nasa chose the original 7 Mercury astronauts. When my neck hurt, and I couldn't read anymore comments, I scrolled down ... trying to find the end of the comments. There was 'no end'. There were 'hundreds', and I couldn't get to the end. I wonder if the amount of comments was a 'record amount'.

I think Elon has successfully captured the attention of a good number of us, which was one of his many goals. And is why he makes himself available for Tim, and so many other public appearances. And yes, it is an intrusion on his focus, as you could see in the car, and on site. He was thinking of many many parts of this operation.
Here, several commenters were concerned about Elon being tired, or having back pain. I have 'created', and I will tell you, to go from concept, to product, gave me tons of energy. I would awaken and throw myself into my project. 12-17 hours was normal. It was exciting. Physically tired was easily overcome by enthusiasm. And at the end of any day, I felt great. Accomplished. Thrilled. And looking forward to tomorrow.

Elon is not being worn down. He is energized. He is excited. He will live long and he will be healthy. And he will sleep well at night. Passion makes us 'Alive'.

This raw look behind the scenes, especially seeing the interaction between Elon Musk and his employees, is somewhat surreal.  Could you imagine what other time in history technology could allow us to get an intimate, near real-time look into something like this?  I mean, we're seeing one of the wealthiest people on the planet walking through the construction site where he pioneers space technology to make mankind interplanetary, having technical conversations about progress and getting hugged by construction workers.  Elon Musk is one of a kind and we're gifted with the ability to witness this aspect of his story, which may very well be part of humanity's story.  Thanks, Tim Dodd!

OMG, this video was not what I was expecting after the first two. This video seemed to reveal the true amount of stress Elon is under. I have no doubt that Elon can handle a lot, but I believe he's losing track of what is most important to humanity. He's done amazing things with Tesla, and with Starlink, to advance technology for the immediate benefit all of humanity, but I'm really questioning whether it makes sense to build a Mars colony for the sheer sake of becoming an interplanetary species. I think there needs to be a better reason for us to become an interplanetary species at this time. Mining, or low gravity manufacturing may provide some reasons to colonize somewhere besides Earth, but so far, orbital space stations seem to make more sense than Mars, and I think it would be wiser for Elon to be spending resources on things that would provide a more immediate and concrete benefit to society.
Of all the billionaires, I like Elon the most, but frankly, this is yet another example of why it is such a bad idea that a small number of individuals are allowed to be entrusted with such large portions of the total wealth in the world. That wealth is too often squandered on selfish things to the determent of society.

I've got a big question I've never seen answered. Are there plans to source biomethane or ambient-synthesized synth methane or some other renewable methane? For that matter, are there plans to source renewable kerosene for Merlin?

If humanity one day launches hundreds of boosters per day, that will be a huge source of liberated carbon in the atmosphere. The longer term solution might be an orbital ring or some other sort of loop momentum device. Until such megastructures are built, synthesizing fuel from the atmosphere will be all we have to make space launches sustainable. (I recall the field of miles of solar panels around Ender's launch shuttle in Ender's Game presumably powering a fuel creation process. I can't believe Elon hasn't thought about this.)
The wheels on the Tesla go round and round.

To those who say 'we must fix all problems on Earth before focusing on the Moon or Mars', I say that the solutions to fixing Earth's problems are in space. The very plan, the attempt and the act of living on Mars will form and resolve those solutions. Already NASA toilets make clean water and fertilizer to grow food. Those toilets are being used to great benefit in India. No waste.
Now imagine all the closed resource loop technology from Mars applied to our cities on Earth. Soon we will realise how precious and abundant Earth's biosphere is. But first humans must leave our biosphere to not take it for granted. The feeling of the little blue earth picture from the Moon will be nothing compared to how we will feel about Earth in the future. On Mars there can be no waste. But we can only do all that when some of our people leave Earth to live on Mars and the Moon.

I had an idea, and I mean it's future needs, but when the Lunar and Mars projects really start going in earnest with Starship, and also for the smaller rocket boosters from the falcon 9 are being used more frequently, I was thinking that for the reusability supply chain, Elon really might consider (and likely has) another several ships.

The landing barge type ships can basically stay near where they need to be for receiving booster landings. Once the boosters are landed and temporarily secured. Another ship comes in and cranes it off of the barge and into locks on the carrier ship.

The carrier ship can carry a dozen or even dozens of boosters at once, whatever is projected to be required, and some of the refitting procedure can actually be started at sea on this bigger more stable ships, like the deep cleaning and preparation for the engines to be refit.

When the storage ship has enough boosters to justify a trip it returns to shore, and it's sister ship now stands by to offload the landing pads. If we are going to be doing multiple launches per day, or even several per week, at a certain point the logistics justify a carrier type ship designed hold and move multiple boosters, and to be stable for working on them, perhaps with hydraulic outriggers that can be retracted for the journey to shore but deployed for crane operations and refitting operations.

The storage can be as easy or as complicated as is desired, but I would err towards a little complication since a lot of prep work can be done with proper locks and moveable maintenance bays that are designed for cleaning and partial disassembly of certain components to speed the refit process on the other end. When the booster gets to shore, it is already decontaminated, partially inspected, and if it helps, the engines can be removed or partially dissassembled to speed retrofit onshore.

It just seems that when things speed up and there are more moving parts, this extra component will be required, and as long as you are transporting multiple stages, which means days on board, you might as well have a dedicated crew cleaning them and prepping them for refit.

As things go forward we might even see storage ships that can not only transport and store, but land boosters as needed. Currently the barge style landing pads can only land and hold one booster because of size considerations and probably safety. It is inefficient to make the trip for only one booster I would think, when many boosters are coming each week. Then again, I don't really know how far they have to travel.

Just some random thoughts I had. Perhaps the Ship should replace the barge completely, and have a reenforced upper deck to land, that can open up and that has an elevator system to move the landed booster to another part of the ship, eliminating the barge completely.

This should be safe if the outside of the ship is armored for mishaps and the crew is in safe keeping for the landings. Thoughts?

Even if the distance to shore is not too distant, you can never predict what restrictions the idiots in power may levy in the future. This would give Elon more flexibility to get around regulations designed to slow down his freedom loving ventures. Certain people will never accept ideas and industries that they cannot control and exploit and they would rather inhibit them. But I digress.

A bigger ship might require a pier or dedicated dock. I do not know what the draft or facilities are currently near the refitting shops. But I assume it would be worthwhile to build whatever simple conveyance required that would allow the larger ship envisioned to offload its cargo of multiple boosters of multiple types, in an automated fashion that would have them on custom trailers and down the road to starbase in a matter of hours. An excellent short documentary about the realities and changes of focus and mission that happen from day to day (and in some cases hour to hour) in an overall drive to get to very important milestones.  Showing the OLP prior to the table installation (and bringing into scale the massive cranes used in tandem to lift it up there), along with the shimming work that is as important as the table installation itself is just a tiny part of the massive structures and infrastructure that's going up.  It also gave us daily followers some keys to what's coming up.  The QD arms are still busy being buiilt.  B3 may be scrap for now, as B4 has the focus, and ship 20 has it's test stand ready to rock at pad B once they get the tiling finished.  Ending the interview by hoppy (and discussing early spacex history) shows just how fast and far they've come.  A snapshot in time of what will be talked about for years to come.

comment_text: In my youth, I was fortunate to have a beautiful aunt who was head buyer for a large group of department stores. She looked like the young beautiful Marilyn Monroe when she had kind of short curly more naturally blonde hair. Spectacular. It was nice to be around her and to talk with her. One day we somehow got to talking about how to deal with pressure and especially pressure in the work place. She gave me some advise that I would give to Musk. I think he needs it. Sit down on a comfortable high back check with arms. Lay your arms on the arms of the chair. Relax. Relax. Take several deep breaths and sink wholly into that chair. Close your eyes and think good thoughts. After no more than a few minutes you'll be energized and ready to go. Her name was Mildred. She is gone now but it has always been good advice. Watching Tim interview Elon on this channel rates as extraordinary viewing. I've been inspired to learn about full flow staged combustion engines, how solving the right problem can be the most challenging part of any successful workflow, and how much humility, flexibility and willingness to invest in the best processes can be so vital in SpaceX's breakneck rate of progress.

But I think the last half-hour to 45mins of the time here with Elon felt a little bit strained. Of course it's easy for some random Youtube commentor like myself do some Monday morning quarterbacking and say,
"Hey Tim, two things:
1) when you're interviewing, if you get the feeling that the interviewer doesn't want to answer the question, tactfully steer away from that line of inquiry. I hate canned talk show interviews where they are clearly following a rehearsed script. But I think if you are lucky enough to have a chance at interviewing Elon again, handing him a list interview topics, a list where Elon could cross off topics he isn't willing to talk about... doing this a minute before starting the interview could save some awkward moments. If you ask him to circle topics he is the most interested an expanding upon, all the better.

2) it might be wise to keep in mind the phrase "always leave them wanting more." For all I know you were promised four hours with Elon, and maybe the idea didn't even occur to you to end the interview earlier than planned.

All I know is there is an entertaining a series of commercials about "the most interesting man in the world." To me and probably many others, there are few candidates in the real world deserving of that honor. Elon is one of those rare candidates, and going forward I hope you continue to get him to share his thoughts with you and the rest of us.

Somebody please tell Elon that he needs to work out. He needs a gym on-site and a trainer. He needs to spare 30 minutes twice a week at the very least to get into slightly better shape and fix that back pain problem. Really, he needs to do two 1-hour workouts a week, but I'm guessing he doesn't want to spare that much time, which is why maybe 30 minute workouts. A good trainer should be able to do something with that.

A workout is more than the time spent on it. You have to change into gym clothes beforehand, then you have to shower immediately after -- it's a real pain. But consider what happens when you never work out: you get injured, and then you have to take time off, and when you finally start working out it will take longer to get into any kind of shape. Elon just has to work a workout into his schedule, and the sooner the better. Just looking at him you can tell he needs to workout.

I’ve been inspired by space since “Godspeed John Glenn”.

It is my earliest memory, I was just 2 years and 4 months old. Obviously, I had absolutely no understanding of what was happening but I knew my mother was nervous/upset while it was happening and then relieved when Glenn was safe. My mother said she was holding me tight and I was hugging her back with my eyes wide open looking right at her face the whole time. She knew how big of an adventure human space exploration is.

I can remember EXACTLY where I was during the Apollo 11 landing and walk on the moon. Likewise with Apollo 12 (switch SCE to AUX), Apollo 13, Apollo 17, Pete Conrad saving Skylab, the first space shuttle launch , the challenger explosion, the Hubble telescope spacewalks, the Columbia explosion, the first launch of the ISS first segment, and, of course, Bob and Doug’s first Dragon mission, I can remember exactly where I was during all those missions.

I wish the idiots over at NASA (and Boeing) would have the same sense urgency that SpaceX does. The latest from them is they have spent over 400 million on a new space suit for the moon and that has NO CHANCE of being ready for the schedule landing on the moon in October 2024. I’ll bet SpaceX could come up with a better suit in a year. NASA already put 12 men on the moon- what’s wrong with Neil Armstrong’s suit? Upgrade the electronics and suit materials and you’re good to go.

I think the “Everyday Astronaut” is the best channel for following SpaceX. Thanks for the great job you guys do.

Godspeed SpaceX. That’s for the whole team from the welders to the crane operators, to that “norminal” guy, to the Astronauts and to everyone else. We are inspired in our daily lives by what you are doing.

Want to know who really made this interview happen. Tim’s persistence in pushing for it, and getting enough backing from his supporters, no doubt was an element, but if the real key was him, or if there was a player within space x that finally made the difference. So hugely valuable to see how casually yet passionately engaged Elon is in his world. He is such a visionary, and very few of us will ever be exposed to someone of his brilliance, let alone be afforded such an intimate look at how he thinks and what motivates him.

It was apparent when Sam started right in on briefing Elon on progress that the tenor of his engagement with Tim switched gears, and he consciously found himself stuck between two roles, hence his somewhat superficial responses to Sam’s input. He quickly regained his role as PR man when Tim stepped in and reestablished himself as the reason for Elon’s presence on the site, but it seemed he was already stretched thin by that point, and he had to abruptly cut the tour. Tim could’ve kept at it for days. Wonderful to get a glimpse of how Elon relates to his crew, and despite the cameras and the reason for their presence, it seemed reasonably genuine how the exchange with Sam was, but hard to ignore how exhausted he seemed after having to try to play both roles simultaneously. He no doubt was additionally internally processing the percentage of his capacity each role was robbing from the other, and given what he feels is at stake, and how precious little time he has, how he can’t afford to squander his contributions.

This was mind blowing to take in.

Hope Tim gets another chance for an update. This was an amazing first attempt, but would be beautiful to see subsequent visits building on lessons learned from this, so as to maximize the fruits offered by the extemporaneous nature of the tour, while recognizing the disruptive departures from that dynamic.

Interesting that they keep switching contractors, I think it is a good move that they start encorporating them into their own staff, hypothetically as a worker (on contract) I'd prefer that. I mean, it will be lost money for the contracting companies themselves though, but overall you don't want to be switching out staff when you have to keep getting new contractors up to speed, you want everyone on site knowing what they are doing at all times.

Also it is good the workers are telling him the faults and work arounds, for example the plates they had to put in, and the inch it was off by. The reason being that in the next construction things can be done to get it more precise and Elon will know of it to make sure it is brought up along with the crew.

The urgency is interesting, and the fact they have a work culture around it. I wonder if they do hype meetings frequently and for how long, as it is pretty hard to instill that culture uniformly without a couple of hours of effort a day. So, I dunno, I expect they have orientation, and then a catchup meeting, planning and assignments, and then after that full briefing they head out on task?

Also interesting that the managers and head people are young and enthusiastic. It makes sense if you are trying to keep at such a fast pace. And this video really shows the kind of hustle the whole team needs, and how each worker has to think of how to pick up the pace and work towards the goal. I guess everyone there is hyper aware of the launches, and look forward to seeing them go up. It kind of reminds me of GATTACA and how they are launching all the time in that movie. I bet all the engineers look to those launches and dream a dream :)

This was by far the best part! Seeing Elon interacting with his crew gives a very rare perspective on how things work at SpaceX: The situation at the site looks very fluid -- multiple high level managers were at the job site in the middle of the night, and were giving updates to Elon on major steps of construction as though these things were decided just a few hours ago and Elon has not heard about them yet.

The legs of the launch platform were significantly not level. To fix that, they first shimmed the top approximately with steel plates, and then used 6 x 200 ton hydraulic jacks to level the "launch ring" accurately, shim it, and then weld in place. One 1" deep weld is enough to hold the whole rocket stack securely in 40 mph wind.

The steel is very thick and welding it is very slow. They have learned that some fabrication procedures did not work very well, and will use different techniques in the next version of the launch ring. The weight will be reduced.

Three different systems are all driven by the same hydraulic system: launch ring hold downs and hoods, and the quick disconnect arm.

---

In the car, Tim was also asking questions about the stuff around them, and got a bunch of interesting answers too:

The yellow thing is definitely the "Quick Disconnect Arm."
The ocean platforms are not presently thought much about.
People asking not to interrupt beach access for the public seem to have been a surprise for SpaceX, and this will be an operational constraint for launches.

---

Elon is focused on creating the momentum for colonizing Mars. Getting the suitable rocket is a subordinate to that goal. Getting Starship into orbit is a goal subordinate to that.

Going to Mars and staying there is the goal, an objective which captures the imagination and could provide all kinds of advantage to humanity. How ever that is not what is important, neither is how long it takes. What is important is how it is done - depending on that, could be the making or undoing of us all, given the advances in AI and associated technology likely to develop out of the endeavour. (and the implications of that technology)
More significant to us all are changes in the Political Arena which could be far more significant, the undermining of democratic principles and systems going apparently unnoticed by all but a few. With a goal of this magnitude and the significance of the effort required to do it, only a fool doesn't consider the path.
So yes - all in favour, a worthwhile pursuit with clearly an eye on the ball. I would say, please just look over your shoulder once in a while. Do not think for one moment that this is the second time we have done this, because that is not the case.

I could tell that Elon was seriously preoccupied and in some pain in this video. The sense of urgency in his language tells me that something is up; he desperately wants to set the steps in motion for interplanetary life before his own mortality becomes an issue. The fact that he has this going through his head, yet remains focused enough to answer Tim's questions, meet his employees and converse with Sam, as well as take in the minutiae like bringing contractors onboard as full SpaceX employees, says a lot.

Billionaires get a lot of stick, some of it well deserved. As much as the man irritates me, I absolutely acknowledge and salute most of what he's doing with SpaceX. Its end goal is not some pipe-dream; its now become a matter of survival of the human species, especially given recent revelations about the pace of climate change.

13:00 people dont understand how single peoples actions can affect the future..
Lets just hypothetically say that there is an "Apophis" heading towards Earth and will hit in 2200, rendering all modern civilization ruined.
IF SpaceX is part of an acceleration to make a Mars colony self-sufficent, and that results in a self-sufficent Mars Colony (with fuel manufacturing and their own parked Spaceships with the ability to go to/from Earth), that achieves self-sufficency in 2150, we're actually looking at a situation where humanity survives, or at least has a chance to survive, when that rock hits in 2200..

NOW, imagine if SpaceX did NOT exist and did NOT act with urgency.
Let's say NASA was still the major player, taking their sweet time with bureaocracy and contractors, resulting in that same self-reliant Mars Colony not being established fully until 2200, 50 years after where we'd be if SpaceX did it. Which is NOT unthinkable. We went to the moon in the 60's, and havent been back since (almost).

Then you'd be looking at an apophis-sized asteroid potentially wiping out all of human civilization, including our space program (if most of it is stationed on earth), and that mars colony might very well wither out and die due to being too young..

Like, this is what people dont understand.
Literally one company, can be the difference in all of humanity surviving or going extinct.
Is this all hypothetical? Yes. But its entirely within the realms of possibility.
And THAT is why we must do it urgently, even 0.01% chance of this happening, is 0.01% chance too high.

So much to chew over here. The technology, organisation, employees, etc is/are all very impressive, and it was a fascinating behind the scenes glimpse into the construction side of Space X, but it was Elon himself who was the most interesting aspect of all three episodes. This is clearly a man who thinks on a different planet to the rest of us and finds it difficult just communicating to 'normal' people, especially if it's not a technical conversation, or they aren't keeping up with his thought process, or listening to what he said (Tim!). But he is also a man on whom all this is taking a huge toll - certainly physically, possibly mentally as well. Perhaps the most revealing moment in all three episodes was when he said Mars wouldn't be ready in his lifetime and then pointed out that he still had a while to go. Looking at the man we've been watching for the last week, I couldn't help but think that, if he wants that lifetime to be long, he needs to sort his work-life balance out pretty pronto. There will be no Mars colony or interplanetary species without Elon.

11:38 “One pass, inside & out, will get up 40 MPH on Booster and Ship.”

Telling words here. Because of the thickness of the steel, they are limited by how big a weld they can achieve and how much stress it can sustain. Sounds like they’ve run the calculations and anything over a 40MPH wind with a fully stacked Super Heavy and Starship could rip the launch mount from the support structure. My guess is that the tower and quick disconnect arm will be called into service to help steady Super Heavy and Starship in high winds.
